_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: fire detection and monitoring system, chemical storage areas, PPE, hazardous waste storage areas, safety showers and eyewash stations, fire suppression systems, hot work areas

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (CalARP Section 2745.3)

Pursuant to the Clean Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, Section 112(r), this Risk Management 
Plan (RMP) document addresses the risk management plan for the Wellhead Power Panoche, LLC 
(WPP) facility located near the towns of Firebaugh and Mendota, Fresno County, California.  
The WPP facility, which is operated by Wellhead Services, Inc. (WSI), is in the business of 
power production and uses anhydrous ammonia (Chemical Abstract Service [CAS] #7664-41-7); a 
regulated substance.  This RMP document has been prepared in accordance with the California 
Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Guidance Document dated June 8, 2004 (California 
Code of Regulations [CCR], Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5).

The WPP plant will process and store ammonia in quantities above the Federal and State 
regulatory threshold quantities and therefore, is submitting this RMP.  A Program 3 RMP 
is being submitted due to the proximity of the facility to off site receptors.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

WSI has an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that is used to respond to emergency situations.  
The plan consists of reporting and notification, mitigation, evacuation, emergency response 
assistance, and medical assistance procedures.  These procedures are discussed in detail in 
Section 7 of this report.

1.2 The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The primary activity at the WPP facility is to generate electricity for sale.  The facility is 
located in a rural part of southwestern Fresno County and consists of a 49.9 megawatt (MW) 
peaking power plant.  The plant is driven by two 25 MW Pratt & Whitney stationary combustion 
gas turbine (CGT).  The units exhaust to a common exhaust train equipped with a Selective 
Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system, which controls emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOX) using 
ammonia (NH3) as a reagent.  The ammonia is stored onsite in two aboveground pre

ssure vessels 
with a capacity of 1,000 gallons each.  The maximum operating capacity of each tank vessel is 
850 liquid gallons (or a total of 1,700 gallons for both tanks). The maximum weight of 
anhydrous ammonia on the site is 8,840 lbs (i.e., 4,420 lbs per vessel).

1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

WSI is dedicated to operating a safe facility.  WSI employees are trained in every aspect of 
hazardous materials management, from using personal protective equipment (PPE) to performing 
maintenance on facility equipment.  All employees are trained in emergency evacuation 
procedures.  A written program for maintaining and inspecting the ongoing integrity of all 
regulated substance process equipment ensures that equipment receives appropriate, regularly 
scheduled maintenance.  Regular inspections are performed to identify the condition and 
reliability of each piece of equipment.  Maintenance on tanks containing ammonia is performed 
monthly (unless otherwise stated) and consists of visual inspection and preventive maintenance 
activities.  General tank condition is inspected and maintenance performed when deemed 
necessary.  Changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures will be 
implemented when necessary.  Before a process change occurs, management of change protocol 
will be implemented to ensure a safe and smooth transition.

WSI will perform a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) for the new ammonia tank and for any 
modification significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.  The 
pre-startup safety review shall confirm that, prior to the introduction of regulated 
substances, the process conforms to all specified regulations and safety requirements.

WSI shall also report any events that may lead to impacts onsite or offsite, regardless of 
whether or not an actual impact does occur, according to the incident investigation program 
contained herein.

1.4 Fi

ve-year Accident History

The WPP facility commenced operations in December 2001.  Between December 2001 and April 2005, 
the facility utilizes aqueous ammonia as the SCR reagent.  During that period, there were no 
accidental releases of aqueous ammonia that resulted in death, injury, or significant property 
damage on site, or known offsite death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property 
damage, or environmental damage.

The introduction of anhydrous ammonia is a new process and will replace the process of aqueous 
ammonia. There have not been any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia within the last five 
years that resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site or known offsite 
death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

1.5 Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

The worst-case release scenario assumes a rupture of the anhydrous ammonia storage tank, 
resulting in a constant release of the entire contents into the air for a duration of 10 
minutes.  This scenario results in the toxic endpoint distance of 1.7 miles from the tanks.  
The alternative release scenario, which is considered a more plausible event, assumes a 
release of about 100 gallons into the air for a duration of 1 minute.  The alternative release 
scenario results in a distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.4 miles.  The toxic endpoint is the 
theoretical distance from the source where the concentration could result in harm if the 
exposure occurred in excess of a one-hour period.  For anhydrous ammonia, the toxic endpoint 
concentration is 0.14 milligrams per liter (mg/L).

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

WSI recognizes that an effective risk management program involves continuous improvement and 
is committed to providing a safe environment for its employees, customers, and the surrounding 
area.  Improvements are implemented when possible to support this commitment.  These 
improvements m

ay include upgrading equipment maintenance procedures, training requirements, 
operating procedures, or system controls.  When possible, a less hazardous substance will be 
substituted for a chemical currently used in the process.

Prior to implementing any changes to these chemical systems, WSI employees will follow 
written Management of Change procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, 
equipment, procedures, and facilities.  These written procedures address the following issues:

* Technical basis for the proposed change(s)
* Impact of the proposed change(s) on health, safety, and environment
* Modification of the operating procedures
* Implementation schedule for the proposed change(s)
* Authorization for the proposed change(s)

Employees involved with affected processes will be informed and trained in the changes as 
early as practicable prior to startup of the process involved.  Written operating procedures 
will be updated as needed.

When nonconformance conditions are identified, WSI will take the following measures:
 
* Shutdown of processes and operations.
* Collecting and containing released waste.
* Removing or isolating containers.
* Monitoring for leaks, ruptures, etc.
* Ensuring sufficient temporary storage of generated wastes.
* Arranging for repair or replacement of affected system areas.

WSI has not identified any equipment, process, or management change that will be implemented 
for this process.  This RMP is for a new process at the plant.
